What is an IDE?

An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is the main tool for programming in any programming language.

It is very important because code could be written anywhere from a word document to a txt file but this makes the process way easier.

Program developers use it because it's a tool that has everything in one, which includes a code compiler, code editor, and a place where the code could be run.

It helps with time also because by having all three tools in one location edits could be done very quickly and effectively.

It could be used without an internet connection if it's on a desktop, as the desktop app could run and be edited without being connected to the internet.

So what's inside an IDE?

Mentioned previously, it has a compiler and an edit tool to use, but there are more that are very helpful.

Some helpful tools included are debuggers, built-in terminal, extensions & plugins, code snippets, and navigating code.

Built-In Terminal

A text-based interface program used to write code within the operating system (e.g., Windows and Linux).

The code could be run through its scripts and the commands embedded in the terminal being used.

Extensions & Plugins

These make the IDE more useful with what's already available to use in the IDE (e.g., Spring Boot, Gradle, Maven, etc.).

Debugger

A tool in the IDE that helps test and find bugs in the code that was being run.

More reasons that developers use IDEs:

It helps with the customization of the code and the code configuration of the language is already embedded in the IDE being used.

It saves plenty of time when figuring out any issues or just plain running the code that was just written.

Syntax and errors are spent heavily when coding, in which having an IDE saves time by highlighting what line the error is occurring.

There are different types of IDEs:

Desktop apps: These can run and be edited without being connected to the internet.

Cloud-based IDEs: These run in web browsers like Chrome or Firefox through a website with a compiler.

Mobile IDEs: These are not used by many but still exist in the industry.

Database IDEs: These are used in MySQL and Oracle in their cloud database setups designed to be used.
